text:
The U.S. President, Donald Trump, is correct.

No reasonable person doubts that climate changes (cyclically, such as season change, and longer term effects influenced to a large extent by shifts in planetary orientation and localized solar variations). So, the purported climate change touted by environmentalist groups, pertains specifically to the claim that significant changes to long-term Earth climate are indicated to be caused primarily by a slight additional output of carbon dioxide due to human industry. It has been a long term scheme to more tightly regulate and tax commercial and personal activity, and given the value of the "climate change" industry (the fees - "donations", lawsuit awards and settlements, unnecessary regulatory fees - energy companies and customers pay to keep activists from disrupting their activities), it's unfortunately unlikely to cease. Hydrocarbon fuels (improperly indicated to be "fossil fuels") have been, and will continue to be a boon to humanity. Hydrocarbon fuels "saved the whales" (humans previously utilized whale oil for illumination sources), freed humans from bondage (industrial machinery powered by hydrocarbon fuels freed humans from a substantial amount of physical labor), created a more humane world for domesticated animals (e.g., combines versus oxen), reduced air pollution relative to human population, created energy sufficient to extend the useful hours of the day to expand education and socialization, and enabled chemistry that contributes substantially to food preservation and medical device technologies that significantly improve and extend human life (e.g., plastics produced from petrochemical stocks).

Most everything progressive politics claims as a policy goal, already exists and is a perquisite developed by the expansion of hydrocarbon fuel use and free market activities over time.
author: D. S.

text: Climate change is very real and one example of proof lies in the vast cypress forest some 60,000 years old, submerged 60 feet down in the Gulf of Mexico off Alabama's coast. The forest grew during the last glacial period when more land was exposed and was subsequently submerged as Earth entered the current interglacial period. Newly discovered shark fossils reveal an even warmer time when the sea had covered much of Southern Alabama.

text:
Global warming is indeed very real and there is scientific proof backing that statement. Not only is the planet's temperature "rising", but ice sheets are shrinking, the sea level is rising, ocean acidification is happening, decreased snow cover, and Arctic sea ice, as well as glaciers, are disappearing. These rising temperatures are also causing changes in seasonal weather patterns thus making extreme weather events such as category 4-5 hurricanes occur more frequently.

https://climate.nasa.gov/evidence/

If you copy and paste the link above in your search bar it will show you a website ran by a Californian Technological Institute. There you will see a list of just some of the main impacts caused by global warming or "climate change".

text:
¬†@T Young¬† i dont think you get it. carbon is not dangerous. carbon reacts with oxygen in the air with forms CO2. CO2 has an incredible property to reflect infrared radiation to some extent (heat), while UV passes through it. UV light from the sun passes through the CO2 as it enters the atmosphere, and the light shifts spectrum down to infrared after hitting the Earth. Most of this energy is absorbed by the earth, but some is reflected back to space.  With the increased C02 in the atmosphere, infrared radiation cannot escape the CO2 barrier lining the atmosphere, and because of it, global temperatures increase.

Have you seen a global temperature vs co2 emissions graph? They are so similar you could easily mistake one for the other. they have a causal correlation that we can directly notice by measuring temperature and CO2 and then comparing. And im hoping i dont have to argue that we are releasing Co2 by emitting fossil fuels. So fossil fuels (manmade) -> CO2 addition in atmosphere -> global temperature increasing. seems manmade to me

text:
According to the Vostok Ice Core Records, CO2 level changes have followed Earth's overall temperature changes at an 800 year lag for the last 800,000 years.  That means that our current CO2 levels are the result of Earth's overall temperature 800 years ago.  World leaders have convinced their dependents that this works in the reverse order, relatively quickly, and that we are to blame, so that they can tax us out of a false shared guilt in order to be able to afford to "fight" climate change, an unstoppable natural cycle.  The following is the source of this information:

Historical Carbon Dioxide Record from the Vostok Ice Core

Investigators
J.-M. Barnola, D. Raynaud, C. Lorius
Laboratoire de Glaciologie et de G√©ophysique de l'Environnement,
CNRS, BP96,
38402 Saint Martin d'Heres Cedex, France

N.I. Barkov
Arctic and Antarctic Research Institute,
Beringa Street 38, 199397,
St. Petersburg, Russia

Period of Record
417,160 - 2,342 years BP

Methods
In January 1998, the collaborative ice-drilling project between Russia, the United States, and France at the Russian Vostok station in East Antarctica yielded the deepest ice core ever recovered, reaching a depth of 3,623 m (Petit et al. 1997, 1999). Ice cores are unique with their entrapped air inclusions enabling direct records of past changes in atmospheric trace-gas composition. Preliminary data indicate the Vostok ice-core record extends through four climate cycles, with ice slightly older than 400 kyr (Petit et al. 1997, 1999). Because air bubbles do not close at the surface of the ice sheet but only near the firn-ice transition (that is, at ~90 m below the surface at Vostok), the air extracted from the ice is younger than the surrounding ice (Barnola et al. 1991). Using semiempirical models of densification applied to past Vostok climate conditions, Barnola et al. (1991) reported that the age difference between air and ice may be ~6000 years during the coldest periods instead of ~4000 years, as previously assumed. Ice samples were cut with a bandsaw in a cold room (at about -15¬∞C) as close as possible to the center of the core in order to avoid surface contamination (Barnola et al. 1983). Gas extraction and measurements were performed with the "Grenoble analytical setup," which involved crushing the ice sample (~40 g) under vacuum in a stainless-steel container without melting it, expanding the gas released during the crushing in a pre-evacuated sampling loop, and analyzing the CO2 concentrations by gas chromatography (Barnola et al. 1983). The analytical system, except for the stainless-steel container in which the ice was crushed, was calibrated for each ice sample measurement with a standard mixture of CO2 in nitrogen and oxygen. For further details on the experimental procedures and the dating of the successive ice layers at Vostok, see Barnola et al. (1987, 1991), Lorius et al. (1985), and Petit et al. (1999).

Trends
There is a close correlation between Antarctic temperature and atmospheric concentrations of CO2 (Barnola et al. 1987). The extension of the Vostok CO2 record shows that the main trends of CO2 are similar for each glacial cycle. Major transitions from the lowest to the highest values are associated with glacial-interglacial transitions. During these transitions, the atmospheric concentrations of CO2 rises from 180 to 280-300 ppmv (Petit et al. 1999). The extension of the Vostok CO2 record shows the present-day levels of CO2 are unprecedented during the past 420 kyr. Pre-industrial Holocene levels (~280 ppmv) are found during all interglacials, with the highest values (~300 ppmv) found approximately 323 kyr BP. When the Vostok ice core data were compared with other ice core data (Delmas et al. 1980; Neftel et al. 1982) for the past 30,000 - 40,000 years, good agreement was found between the records: all show low CO2 values [~200 parts per million by volume (ppmv)] during the Last Glacial Maximum and increased atmospheric CO2 concentrations associated with the glacial-Holocene transition. According to Barnola et al. (1991) and Petit et al. (1999) these measurements indicate that, at the beginning of the deglaciations, the CO2 increase either was in phase or lagged by less than ~1000 years with respect to the Antarctic temperature, whereas it clearly lagged behind the temperature at the onset of the glaciations.

References
Barnola, J.-M., D. Raynaud, A. Neftel, and H. Oeschger. 1983. Comparison of CO2 measurements by two laboratories on air from bubbles in polar ice. Nature 303:410-13.

Barnola, J.-M., D. Raynaud, Y.S. Korotkevich, and C. Lorius. 1987. Vostok ice core provides 160,000-year record of atmospheric CO2. Nature 329:408-14.

Barnola, J.-M., P. Pimienta, D. Raynaud, and Y.S. Korotkevich. 1991. CO2-climate relationship as deduced from the Vostok ice core: A re-examination based on new measurements and on a re-evaluation of the air dating. Tellus 43(B):83- 90.

Delmas, R.J., J.-M. Ascencio, and M. Legrand. 1980. Polar ice evidence that atmospheric CO2 20,000 yr BP was 50% of present. Nature 284:155-57.

Jouzel, J., C. Lorius, J.R. Petit, C. Genthon, N.I. Barkov, V.M. Kotlyakov, and V.M. Petrov. 1987. Vostok ice core: A continuous isotopic temperature record over the last climatic cycle (160,000 years). Nature 329:403-8.

Lorius, C., J. Jouzel, C. Ritz, L. Merlivat, N.I. Barkov, Y.S. Korotkevich, and V.M. Kotlyakov. 1985. A 150,000-year climatic record from Antarctic ice. Nature 316:591-96.

Neftel, A., H. Oeschger, J. Schwander, B. Stauffer, and R. Zumbrunn. 1982. Ice core measurements give atmospheric CO2 content during the past 40,000 yr. Nature 295:220-23.

Pepin, L., D. Raynaud, J.-M. Barnola, and M.F. Loutre. 2001. Hemispheric roles of climate forcings during glacial-interglacial transitions as deduced from the Vostok record and LLN-2D model experiments. Journal of Geophysical Research 106 (D23): 31,885-31,892.

Petit, J.R., I. Basile, A. Leruyuet, D. Raynaud, C. Lorius, J. Jouzel, M. Stievenard, V.Y. Lipenkov, N.I. Barkov, B.B. Kudryashov, M. Davis, E. Saltzman, and V. Kotlyakov. 1997. Four climate cycles in Vostok ice core. Nature 387: 359-360.

Petit, J.R., J. Jouzel, D. Raynaud, N.I. Barkov, J.-M. Barnola, I. Basile, M. Benders, J. Chappellaz, M. Davis, G. Delayque, M. Delmotte, V.M. Kotlyakov, M. Legrand, V.Y. Lipenkov, C. Lorius, L. P√©pin, C. Ritz, E. Saltzman, and M. Stievenard. 1999. Climate and atmospheric history of the past 420,000 years from the Vostok ice core, Antarctica. Nature 399: 429-436.

Raynaud, D., and J.-M. Barnola. 1985. An Antarctic ice core reveals atmospheric CO2 variations over the past few centuries. Nature 315:309-11.

CITE AS: Barnola, J.-M., D. Raynaud, C. Lorius, and N.I. Barkov. 2003. Historical CO2 record from the Vostok ice core. In Trends: A Compendium of Data on Global Change. Carbon Dioxide Information Analysis Center, Oak Ridge National Laboratory, U.S. Department of Energy, Oak Ridge, Tenn., U.S.A.

text:
‚Äã¬†@Waynem Lambert¬† Out of nowhere Greta Thunberg appears. 


We are not talking about Greta, but we are discussing what is beyond that: the enhanced greenhouse effect, mostly known as "climate change" or "global warming".


The claim that "in the 70s scientist said that global cooling will occur" is false. The reason is that in 2008, Peterson did a meta-study on the number of studies who predicted that global cooling will come instead of global warming: 7 out 61 studies showed that this claim was true. Meaning that around 11% of scientists who engaged in this area of research affirm this. And that happened when climate science was a new field. Now there is practically consensus on this issue between scientists and non scientist, given the great amount of proof that validates this process. 


Actually, Al Gore never said that in 10 years there will be an ice age. It was a climate denier blog that falsely invented that story and then became a myth. 


Of course Europe went through a Little  Ice Age because the greenhouse effect wasn't enhanced yet. There were very very very little polluting industries who did not impacted Earth's climate that much because their greenhouse gases weren't produced massively, just a little; therefore, making a very small impact on Earth's climate.


It is evident that Europe went through a little Ice Age because of the planet's actions itself. But in this case, it has been proved over and over that man is causing this by emitting a large amount of greenhouses gases such as CO2, methane, nitrous oxide and hydrofluorcarbons, whose big emissions impacted on Earth's warming significantly.


Please stop denying climate science using strawmans. Both claims that you did are not true.
author: Said Chahud

text:
‚Äã¬†@Waynem Lambert¬† TIME Magazine. Not a scientific magazine. The fact that Time decided to make one article when climatology was recently growing as a science it is not an indicator that global cooling was what the majority of scientist predicted. Actually, Peterson in the meta-study "The myth of the 1970s global cooling scientific consensus" affirms that around 12% (i don't remember the exact numer) of studies made in that time were predicting global cooling, whilst the rest didn't. Also, I highly doubt that the majority of climatologists that made studies concerning future changes in climate where interviewed, since it is impossible for the magazine to compress nearly a 100 statements in one article.

Concerning your second point, yes they were. Around the 2000s blogging was a major activity in the internet, so it did exist.

In reference of what you said on the third paragraph, it is natural indeed. The greenhouse effect it's highly beneficial because it helps us maintain Earth's temperature in living standards. If not for it, we would be extinct. 

The problem is that in the last decades, greenhouses gases have been emitted in surplus, and given that these gases have the property of retaining heat in the atmosphere, it means that Earth's mean temperature is rising. It has been proven many times that this augmentation is caused due to human activities such as combustion of cars, ship, plane engins, burning coal, raising cattle, or paddy fielding. 


Of course that a volcanic eruption produces that amount of greenhouse gases, but do you realize how many times those kind of eruption happen? Probably once in 10000 years, because it is like an IEV 7 (last time it was Krakatoa). Also, the NOAA supports what I am affirming "Human activities emit 60 or more times the amount of carbon dioxide released by volcanoes each year. Large, violent eruptions may match the rate of human emissions for the few hours that they last, but they are too rare and fleeting to rival humanity‚Äôs annual emissions. In fact, several individual U.S. states emit more carbon dioxide in a year than all the volcanoes on the planet combined do." 


Lastly, about Obama. Well, I am not Obama but i'm pretty sure he did because he is not living 200 years. Rising sea levels (if not halted) will increase 7 metres globally in a couple of hundred years. Not right now, the fact that a person wants to buy a beach house does not necessairly mean contradictory behaviour.

text:
The 97 per cent figure derives from a survey sent to 10,257 people with a self-interest in human-induced global warming who published ‚Äúscience‚Äù supported by taxpayer-funded research grants. Replies from 3146 respondents were whittled down to 77 self-appointed climate ‚Äúscientists‚Äù of whom 75 were judged to agree that human-induced warming was taking place. The 97 per cent figure derives from a tribe with only 75 members. What were the criteria for rejecting 3069 respondents? There was no mention that 75 out of 3146 is 2.38 per cent. We did not hear that 2.38 per cent of climate scientists with a self-interest agreed that humans have played a significant role in changing climate and that they are recipients of some of the billions spent annually on climate research.

Another recent paper on the scientific consensus of human-induced climate change was a howler. Such papers can be published only in the sociology or environmental literature.

The paper claimed that published scientific papers showed there was a 97.1 per cent consensus that man had caused at least half of the 0.7C global warming since 1950. How was this 97.1 per cent figure determined? By ‚Äúinspection‚Äù of 11,944 published papers. Inspection is not rigorous scholarship. There was no critical reading and understanding derived from reading 11,944 papers. This was not possible as the study started in March 2012 and was published in mid-2013, hence only a cursory inspection was possible. What was inspected? By whom?

The methodology section of the publication gives the game away. ‚ÄúThis letter was conceived as a ‚Äòcitizen science‚Äô project by volunteers contributing to the Skeptical Science website (www.skepticalscience.com). In March 2012, we searched the Institute for Scientific Information Web of Science for papers published from 1991-2011 using topic searches for ‚Äòglobal warming‚Äô or ‚Äòglobal climate change‚Äô.‚Äù

This translates as: This study was a biased compilation of opinions from non-scientific, politically motivated volunteer activists who used a search engine for key words in 11,944 scientific papers, were unable to understand the scientific context of the use of ‚Äúglobal warming‚Äù and ‚Äúglobal climate change‚Äù, who rebadged themselves as ‚Äúcitizen scientists‚Äù to hide their activism and ignorance, who did not read the complete papers and were unable to evaluate critically the diversity of science published therein.

The conclusions were predictable because the methodology was not dispassionate and involved decisions by those who were not independent.

As part of a scathing critical analysis of this paper by real scientists, the original 11,944 papers were read and the readers came to a diametrically opposite conclusion. Of the 11,944 papers, only 41 explicitly stated that humans caused most of the warming since 1950 (0.3 per cent). Of the 11,944 climate ‚Äúscience‚Äù papers, 99.7 per cent did not say that carbon dioxide caused most of the global warming since 1950. It was less than 1 per cent and not one paper endorsed a man-made global warming catastrophe.

Political policy and environmental activism rely on this fraudulent 97 per cent consensus paid for by the taxpayer to rob the taxpayer further with subsidies for bird-and-bat-chomping wind turbines, polluting solar panels and handouts to those with sticky fingers in the international climate industry. It‚Äôs this alleged 97 per cent consensus that has changed our electricity from cheap and reliable to expensive and unreliable.

Activists with no skin in the game are setting the scene for economic suicide. Time for yellow shirts to shirt-front politicians about their uncritical acceptance of a fraud that has already cost the community hundreds of billions of dollars.

text:
Imagine you had a greenhouse in your garden. You have just built the greenhouse, the temperature inside is just like outside. After a couple of hours, at noon, you measure temperature in the greenhouse - it is let¬¥s say 40 degrees Celsius. You measure the temperature next to your greenhouse, it is let¬¥s say 25 degrees Celsius. This proves the booth from glass that you have just built is a greenhouse because the temperature in it is higher than the temperature at another place that is not covered by any greenhouse.
Right? Get it? OK. 
Let¬¥s go to the Moon, shall we?
The temperature on the Moon is very low at night. So we wait till noon. The temperature on the Moon at noon is 130 degrees Celsius. You can check it out any time on the internet.
There is no greenhouse on the Moon, the Moon has got no atmosphere.
Well, let¬¥s do the same measurement on Earth. The night is cold, so we wait till noon. The temperature on Earth at noon is let¬¥s say 30 degrees Celsius.
Same Sun, the same distance from the Sun. (the Sun is 389x further from Earth than the Moon is)
The Earth has got the atmosphere. 
Is the Earth¬¥s atmosphere a greenhouse or not? What do you think?
Can it be a greenhouse if you measure the higher temperature on the Moon without any "greenhouse"?
The Earth¬¥s atmosphere is no greenhouse, morons! It is nothing but insulation. The Earth is not losing its temperature that fast at night as the moon does because the atmosphere only works as insulation at night, there is no sunlight at night at all so we cannot speak about the greenhouse effect.

Here's another example: In 1930 Clair Cameron Patterson noticed that people were getting sick from lead (Chemical name Pb) from excessive pollution from cars. He understood it's because lead was used as an oil-component, and entered a legal rights case against General Motors (United States largest car-producer, and owner of Ethyl Corporations which produced this lead-based component), which lasted about 35 years. General Motors hired their own scientist (Robert A. Kehoe) to prove lead was safe, which he could "prove" because you an manipulate data quite easily. text: Christopher Wayne it‚Äôs apparent that you do not believe in the theory of global warming. Your ignorance is most likely caused by the Dunn-Kurginger (probably misspelt) Effect. I‚Äôll try to stop or at least reduce your ignorance. Everything is made out of atoms. Atoms are the building block of all baryotic matter. An atom is made out of protons, neutrons, and electrons. An electron is a small object that circles around the atom. The electron carries a negative charge. Not too complicated, is it. Now imagine that light is a cookie, and electrons are children. Children are picky; they only want whole amounts of cookies. They don‚Äôt want a half cookie, a 2/3 cookie, they ONLY want a whole number of cookies (1,2,3...). Electrons are the same way. They only absorb certain values of light. Now when the Sun‚Äôs light hits the atmosphere, the electrons only take in certain wavelengths of the light. Now the light has entered earth. When the light enters earth the reflects off of various objects and then starts moving toward space. But there is a barrier blocking the light from escaping the earth‚Äîthe electrons. Remember, the electron only takes in certain wavelengths of light, and the light going towards space does not have the wavelength needed for the electron to let it through. All electrons do this, but electrons from greenhouse gases are the most picky, making light harder to escape them. It‚Äôs like having a door but with the wrong key to unlock it. Because of this, the light is trapped and it stays on earth. This heats up to earth due to the conversion of radiant energy to thermal energy. Congrats, now you‚Äôve had an introductory lesson in quantum mechanics! Now, everything I said is of course blasphemy, the government just wants you to believe that‚Äîright? Except that this phenomenon has been directly observed google ‚Äúultraviolet catastrophe‚Äù and it was done independent of climate change research. The reason why you guys deny global warming is simply because of your ignorance. Hopefully, I‚Äôve cleared your ignorance (ah, let‚Äôs be honest I haven‚Äôt‚ÄîYouTube commenters are the most stubborn) and hopefully my explanation was not too complicated. Before you send me your ‚Äúproofs‚Äù as to why global warming is fake first disprove what I‚Äôve just stated. Do not dodge the question. Have a good day.

The point is that the best way to combat climate change would be to advance our technology, not trying to step backwards in technology to try solving a problem that won‚Äôt affect us negatively for a long time. If we can finally switch to nuclear power or geothermal and found colonies in space, then we don‚Äôt have to worry about climate change on earth too much. It‚Äôll take a long time but if we put our priorities in order, it won‚Äôt take as long. Also even if climate change takes affect beforehand, the worst that will happen is that sea levels will rise and it‚Äôll affect not many people as they can move more inland where there is plenty of space, it‚Äôll get hotter which brings positives and negatives and ice in the North Pole will shrink but ice in the South Pole will increase. author: Expired Pancakes

text: Natsuki ‚ÄúWe should use advancements in science to stop climate change‚Äù. Given this statement I can see that you‚Äôre a cornucopian. Cornucopians believe that we can use advancements in science to stop a problem. This idea is very illogical, and I‚Äôll explain why. If I have an assignment due next month, I can just say ‚Äúoh, I‚Äôll do it later.‚Äù Then as the due date approaches I will still say ‚Äúoh I‚Äôll do the assignment later no worries‚Äù, and then by the time the due date comes I haven‚Äôt done the assignment. That is called procrastinating. This is the logical equivalent for your cornucopian beliefs. Saying ‚Äúoh we will have advancements in tech so we can solve it‚Äù is just procrastinating. You cannot guarantee that will happen. You cannot try to plan how you live your life from a coin toss. I‚Äôm not saying that advancements in science won‚Äôt help at all, they definitely will, but they cannot stop the entire problem. CO2 still warms up the atmosphere regardless of what technology we have. It‚Äôs basic QM. To stop GW with a machine we‚Äôd need to find a way to capture all light that is emitted from random locations which is impossible, given that light is the fastest thing in the universe and we cannot predict where the light will go. This is a fundamental theorem in physics. Well, future tech can solve that, *right*? Like back in the day, people said that it‚Äôs impossible to go to space. This is not the same case. In this case, the laws of physics forbid you being able to capture all the heat made by CO2 and other greenhouse gases. If we want to stop global warming, a simple machine won‚Äôt cut it. We‚Äôd have to stop emitting so much CO2. Nuclear power is the best power we have and it‚Äôs harmless. Nuclear power also provides more energy than power plants. This is a very good alternative. But we cannot switch to nuclear and still burn coal, that‚Äôs like washing the dishes and using a dirty sponge.

author: CanYaDigIt

text: Fermion Physics i never said stop it, i said combat it. Also i never said helping decrease the amount of CO2 we release into the environment was bad, actually i think we should. What i said was that we should focus on switching to nuclear and geothermal power and focus more on advancing science in order to combat climate change by slowing it down or even leaving the planet and colonizing mars or just moving more inland would be a solution. I don‚Äôt like the usage of fossil fuels because i prefer nuclear and geothermal but if we focus on only planting trees and ignore switching to a more effective source of power, it‚Äôll be worst for us later on. That‚Äôs what I‚Äôm trying to say.
author: Expired Pancakes

text: Fermion Physics also by not trying to step back in our tech to solve it, i don‚Äôt mean to continue using fossil fuels. I mentioned this earlier but we should focus more funds on an alternate more effective source of power such as nuclear or geothermal, not air or hydro which won‚Äôt commonly be found in space. If we were to use air power on mars, we would either get barely any air or harsh winds that would break the windmill. And there are no known rivers on mars that would be able to support hydro power which is why i believe in nuclear and geothermal. You‚Äôre completely right in everything you said but i just have a different focus and way to go about climate change. But i think we can both agree most people nowadays are taking things out of proportion for monetary gain (you donate money and they keep a lot of it). Also the media uses the headlines of climate change to freak people out and gain more views. Well i think we had a productive conversation and nice exchange of ideas. Good talk.

This extreme reduction in CO2 is the result of sea life using the CO2 to make shells. More CO2 in the atmosphere means healthier plant life and consequently more food. By releasing minor amounts of CO2 into the atmosphere, we have bought ourselves a little more time before all the plants die due to CO2 starvation. When the plants die, we die. Let's release as much CO2 as we can.

Add to that, that we are presently in a relatively cool period on a geological time scale. The earth is cooler now than usual.

Another interest thing to note is that the ice caps on Mars receded at the same rate and at the same time as the ice caps on Earth. They grew grapes in England during the middle ages, waaaaay too cold for that now. Are you saying that the warmth of the middle ages was caused by CO2 emissions?

As a green house gas, CO2 accounts for 0.000000000000002% of the warming. Try listening to some scientists who AREN'T on the government's payroll.

Two things history shows us:
When the temperature warms up, life thrives and civilizations flourish. When the temperature falls, life struggles and civilizations fall. Warmer is better.

The gradual increase in temp is a lie. The "hockey stick" graph is a lie. Solar activity didn't 'peak' around the time industrialization started. It's waxes and wanes. It was peaking during the moon missions, for example. It was peaking again during the 90s. We've been cooling since then.

I'm not arguing that humans don't have an effect on the environment. But changing the world's temp with CO2? That's not even possible. CO2 is a very, very, very, very, very weak greenhouse gas, and add to that that it accounts for something like 0.03% of the atmosphere. It's a 'trace' gas. Anyone who actually thinks CO2 is causing global warming is a moron. As the Earth's temp rises, the oceans release more CO2. The higher concentrations of CO2 are an effect of the warming NOT the cause of it.

text:
It was the year 1958, to be precise, when NASA first observed that changes in the solar orbit of the earth, along with alterations to the earth‚Äôs axial tilt, are both responsible for what climate scientists today have dubbed as ‚Äúwarming‚Äù (or ‚Äúcooling,‚Äù depending on their agenda). In no way, shape, or form are humans warming or cooling the planet by driving SUVs or eating beef, in other words.

But NASA has thus far¬†failed¬†to set the record straight, and has instead chosen to sit silently back and watch as liberals freak out about the world supposedly¬†ending in 12 years¬†because of too much livestock, or too many plastic straws.

In the year 2000, NASA did publish information on its Earth Observatory website about the Milankovitch Climate Theory, revealing that the planet is, in fact, changing due to extraneous factors that have absolutely nothing to do with human activity. But, again, this information has yet to go mainstream, some 19 years later, which is why deranged, climate-obsessed leftists have now begun¬†to claim¬†that we really only have 18¬†months¬†left before the planet dies from an excess of carbon dioxide (CO2).

There's one very good motive for this Co2-global warming scam and this is it:

text:
That isn't really what he meant.
The main reason he ditched the Paris Agreement (which every country should do) is because they were charging America and tax paying Americans billions of dollars every year for not meeting PA's ridiculously high standards. Which are always impossible to meet, and therefore costs countries around the world trillions when combined. 
And there is no real record of where that money goes. 
While I will agree that Climate Change and Global Warming does need addressing I cannot agree that it's as bad as they make out nor that it is entirely humans fault.
The climate itself is changing drastically, even if humans weren't here, the temperature of thee environment would still be increasing. 
The earth goes through its own climate changes every now and then and we have to take that into serious consideration when looking into climate change. 

Also, one of the worst offenders that cause probably the worst amount of sheer damage to the environment and earth itself are people on Vegan diets.
Vegan food producers are responsible for destroying millions of acres of rainforests. To the point that when the producers stop producing soya, the ground/soil will no longer have the nuitriants to grow any plant life at all!
So the rainforest will never be able to grow back.
On top of that, with the alarming amount of trees they've taken down they have taken billions of pounds of oxygen out of the environment which we will never be able to recover. Plus, the sheer amount of CO2 that isn't being absorbed by trees is also adding to our lack of breathable air. 
Not to mention the billions of animals and bugs being wiped out. Bugs that also protect us by devouring decaying bodies and other things. 
Vegans are not helping, and neither is the amount of overconsumption by meat and dairy eaters - overconsumption that ends up not actually being consumed and adds to the crazy amount of waste produced. 

We don't need things like the Paris Agreement. We need to regress back to how we used to consume. 
Ditch unhealthy Vegan diets and slow down with the amount of food eaten every day, go back to 3 normal meals a day and cut out all the junk we consume and waste. That'll go such a long way in helping.

text: In the history of mankind, 50% of all carbon released into the atmosphere occurred in the last 30 years. The burning of fossil fuels and chemical-intensive industrial agriculture are the main drivers of climate change. The good news is that humans have the power to stop, and potentially reverse, climate change, but the solution is not fancy new carbon-capturing technology (biochar is the way to go as far as sequestration goes / it would also reduce the use of artificial fertilizer production and nitrous oxide emissions). A significant part of the solution to climate change is to harness the power of Mother Nature in the form of organic regenerative agriculture and the restoration of forests, peatlands, mangroves and other ecosystem habitats capable of drawing down and storing excess atmospheric carbon.

text:
How big is the Climate Change Industrial Complex today? Surprisingly, no one seems to be keeping track of all the channels of funding. A few years ago Forbes magazine went through the federal budget and estimated about $150 billion in spending on climate change and green energy subsidies during President Obama‚Äôs first term.

That didn‚Äôt include the tax subsidies that provide a 30 percent tax credit for wind and solar power ‚Äî so add to those numbers about $8 billion to $10 billion a year. Then add billions more in costs attributable to the 29 states with renewable energy mandates that require utilities to buy expensive ‚Äúgreen‚Äù energy.


Worldwide the numbers are gargantuan. Five years ago, a leftist group called the Climate Policy Initiative issued a study which found that ‚ÄúGlobal investment in climate change‚Äù reached $359 billion that year. Then to give you a sense of how money-hungry these planet-saviors are, the CPI moaned that this spending ‚Äúfalls far short of what‚Äôs needed‚Äù a number estimated at $5 trillion.

text:
Carbon
Carbon dioxide (CO2) is an important trace gas in Earth's atmosphere. It is an integral part of the carbon cycle, a biogeochemical cycle in which carbon is exchanged between the Earth's oceans, soil, rocks and the biosphere. Plants and other photoautotrophs use solar energy to produce carbohydrate from atmospheric carbon dioxide and water by photosynthesis. Almost all other organisms depend on carbohydrate derived from photosynthesis as their primary source of energy and carbon compounds. CO2 absorbs and emits infrared radiation at wavelengths of 4.26 ¬µm (asymmetric stretching vibrational mode) and 14.99 ¬µm (bending vibrational mode) and consequently is a greenhouse gas that plays a vital role in regulating Earth's surface temperature through the greenhouse effect.

Concentrations of CO2 in the atmosphere were as high as 4,000 parts per million (ppm) during the Cambrian period about 500 million years ago to as low as 180 ppm during the Quaternary glaciation of the last two million years. Estimates based on reconstructed temperature records suggests that the amount of CO2 during the last 420 million years ago was with ~2000 ppm highest during the Devonian (‚àº400 Myrs ago) and Triassic (220‚Äì200 Myrs ago), with a few maximum estimates ranging up to ‚àº3,700¬±1,600 ppm (215 Myrs ago). Global annual mean CO2 concentration has increased by more than 45% since the start of the Industrial Revolution, from 280 ppm during the 10,000 years up to the mid-18th century[2] to 410 ppm as of mid-2018. The present concentration is the highest in the last 800,000 and possibly even the last 20 million years. The increase has been caused by human activities, particularly the burning of fossil fuels and deforestation. This increase of CO2 and other long-lived greenhouse gases in Earth's atmosphere has produced the current episode of global warming. About 30‚Äì40% of the CO2 released by humans into the atmosphere dissolves into oceans, rivers and lakes, which has produced ocean acidification.
author: Jim Kogelheide

text:
History of climate change and the Cenozoic era
Climate change is the greatest Earthly phenomenon there is! As our Earth's climates have changed - due to the variable levels of CO2 (among other gases) - throughout the Earth's history, we have witnessed a variety of unique global environments. The ages of the dinosaur saw a climate very different than any other time period, lasting millions of years. Then 'something' changed and the Earth evolved to its present state. We are now living in what we call the Cenozoic Age or Epoch and it is classified by the most varied life forms of plants and animals in the entire Earth's history! Pretty impressive!!!! Ironically though, the Cenozoic Era has been a period of long-term cooling. After the tectonic creation of Drake Passage at 41 million years ago, when South America fully detached from Antarctica during the Oligocene, the climate cooled significantly due to the advent of the Antarctic Circumpolar Current which brought cool deep Antarctic water to the surface. The cooling trend continued in the Miocene, with relatively short warmer periods. When South America became attached to North America creating the Isthmus of Panama around 2.8 million years ago, the Arctic region cooled due to the strengthening of the Humboldt and Gulf Stream currents, eventually leading to the glaciations of the Quaternary ice age. So this should impress upon any readers just how significant and magical climate change actually is. The issue now facing humanity is the fact that our burning of fossil fuels and many other activities is affecting the dynamics of our atmosphere and our oceans. We have been feeding an aggressive climate change since the Industrial Revolution began almost 300 years ago!
author: Jim Kogelheide

text:
How CO2 warms
Sunlight enters the atmosphere as ultraviolet and visible light; some of this solar energy is then radiated back toward space as infrared energy, or heat. The atmosphere is 78 percent nitrogen and 21 percent oxygen, which are both gases made up of molecules containing two atoms. These tightly bound pairs don't absorb much heat. But the greenhouse gases, including carbon dioxide, water vapor and methane, each have at least three atoms in their molecules. These loosely bound structures are efficient absorbers of the long-wave radiation (also known as heat) bouncing back from the planet's surface. When the molecules in carbon dioxide and other greenhouse gases re-emit this long-wave radiation back toward Earth's surface, the result is warming. Scientists also know that the extra carbon in the atmosphere is the very same carbon that comes from burning fossil fuels. By analyzing molecular variations called isotopes, researchers can trace the origin of atmospheric carbon. That's not to say that the climate is as simple as an actual greenhouse. Many factors influence global temperatures, including volcanic eruptions and variations in the solar cycle and Earth's orbit that alter the amount of sunlight reaching the planet. But scientists know that volcanoes and the sun aren't to blame for recent climate change. Volcanic carbon dioxide emissions have been, at most, a hundredth of human CO2 emissions since 1750. In addition, volcanic eruptions cause changes for short timescales of about two years, not the longer-term changes being observed currently. The sun is more complex, but researchers have found that the recent solar-cycle minimum (between 1986 and 2008) was actually lower than the previous two solar-cycle minimums (the sun moves between quiet minimums and active maximums about once every five years). If anything, recent solar activity should have resulted in cooling, not warming. Likewise, a 2012 study found that between 2005 and 2010, a period when solar activity was low, the Earth still absorbed 0.58 watts of excess energy per square meter, continuing to warm despite the lower level of solar energy going into the system.
author: Jim Kogelheide

text:
The Earth is Greener
From a quarter to half of Earth‚Äôs vegetated lands has shown significant greening over the last 35 years largely due to rising levels of atmospheric carbon dioxide, according to a new study published in the journal Nature Climate Change on April 25.
An international team of 32 authors from 24 institutions in eight countries led the effort, which involved using satellite data from NASA‚Äôs Moderate Resolution Imaging Spectrometer and the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration‚Äôs Advanced Very High Resolution Radiometer instruments to help determine the leaf area index, or amount of leaf cover, over the planet‚Äôs vegetated regions. The greening represents an increase in leaves on plants and trees equivalent in area to two times the continental United States.
Green leaves use energy from sunlight through photosynthesis to chemically combine carbon dioxide drawn in from the air with water and nutrients tapped from the ground to produce sugars, which are the main source of food, fiber and fuel for life on Earth. Studies have shown that increased concentrations of carbon dioxide increase photosynthesis, spurring plant growth.
However, carbon dioxide fertilization isn‚Äôt the only cause of increased plant growth‚Äînitrogen, land cover change and climate change by way of global temperature, precipitation and sunlight changes all contribute to the greening effect. To determine the extent of carbon dioxide‚Äôs contribution, researchers ran the data for carbon dioxide and each of the other variables in isolation through several computer models that mimic the plant growth observed in the satellite data.
Results showed that carbon dioxide fertilization explains 70 percent of the greening effect, said co-author Ranga Myneni, a professor in the Department of Earth and Environment at Boston University. ‚ÄúThe second most important driver is nitrogen, at 9 percent. So we see what an outsized role CO2 plays in this process.‚Äù
About 85 percent of Earth‚Äôs ice-free lands is covered by vegetation. The area covered by all the green leaves on Earth is equal to, on average, 32 percent of Earth‚Äôs total surface area - oceans, lands and permanent ice sheets combined. The extent of the greening over the past 35 years ‚Äúhas the ability to fundamentally change the cycling of water and carbon in the climate system,‚Äù said lead author Zaichun Zhu, a researcher from Peking University, China, who did the first half of this study with Myneni as a visiting scholar at Boston University.
Every year, about half of the 10 billion tons of carbon emitted into the atmosphere from human activities remains temporarily stored, in about equal parts, in the oceans and plants. ‚ÄúWhile our study did not address the connection between greening and carbon storage in plants, other studies have reported an increasing carbon sink on land since the 1980s, which is entirely consistent with the idea of a greening Earth,‚Äù said co-author Shilong Piao of the College of Urban and Environmental Sciences at Peking University.
While rising carbon dioxide concentrations in the air can be beneficial for plants, it is also the chief culprit of climate change. The gas, which traps heat in Earth‚Äôs atmosphere, has been increasing since the industrial age due to the burning of oil, gas, coal and wood for energy and is continuing to reach concentrations not seen in at least 500,000 years. The impacts of climate change include global warming, rising sea levels, melting glaciers and sea ice as well as more severe weather events.

text:
The reason for state intervention to prevent external effects of environmental pollution. 

In theory, a perfect market economy, the principle of free exchange and free pricing lead to a Pareto-efficient distribution of individual benefits. In reality, in every economy, whether planned or open there are market failures. This is empirical fact not only proven by many economists like Joseph E. Stiglitz in the field of financial science, game theory but also throughout history (see US Subprime crisis or the collapse of the Sowjet Union). 

The welfare theorem shows that the market fundamentally leads to a Pareto-efficient allocation. Although, the market economy does not provide an efficient allocation under the following conditions:

1.External effects 2. Incomplete competition 3. Incomplete information

State intervention can increase welfare and affect more than just property rights and tax collection. External effects arise when the advantages and disadvantages of economic activity incurred by other people are not compensated by prices. Environmental pollution and thus resulting climate change is the perfect example. Individual benefit maximization then does not necessarily lead to the macroeconomic benefit maximum. Please compare the Prisoner's Dilemma. 

Uncoordinated behavior can lead to Pareto-inefficient allocation. For instance, the installation of a catalyst in a car has a positive external effect, which is not taken into account in individual benefit maximization. Same goes for cerosin prices which do not reflect real cost taking into account the negative external effects on the climate. 

To prevent such failures the public sector should perform three main functions. Allocation, distribution, and stabilization. Possible instruments are taxes, subventions regulations or public provision of goods, services, and finance. 

If the nations on earth do not coordinate individual behavior on environmental pollution and put policies in place to achieve the agreed 1.5 grad celsius temperature raise form the Paris agreement by 2050 greenhouse emission will continue to rise. Then, in 12 only to years from now, the earth will fall into so-called positive feedback loops and humanity won't make it through that. Again this is scientifically proven for decades now. 

It might be that we the YOUNG are waked but the powerful older generations the lobbyists the CEO's the politician's the banker's control and they are not environmentally conscious for whatever reason probably greed and inflexibility. We have no time to wait for the ignorant majority of people living on this planet to wake up. We need system change, not climate change when do we need it NOW!

text:
¬†@Ellie Horne¬† Actually, very few scientists believe that climate change is caused by humans. That whole "97% of climate scientists agree ..." thing turned out to be deliberate misinformation. What happened was that climate alarmists went through 11,000 research papers, except they didn't bother to actually read any of them, they just searched for certain phrases like "climate change" and "global warming" and they then assumed that any paper that had one of these phrases in it supported human caused climate change. This was debunked, however, by a second group who actually bothered to read the papers. This second group found that almost none of the scientists who'd written these papers believed that human were responsible ... only about 0.3%.


So while 97% of the papers had one or more of the phrases searched for in them, only 0.3% attributed it to humans being the cause.

Nobody was complaining about climate change 11,000 years ago, when the glaciers first began to retreat from the North American continent, and of course the rest of the northern hemisphere.  That was what truly could have been called a period of global warming,

text:
It was the year 1958, to be precise, when NASA first observed that changes in the solar orbit of the earth, along with alterations to the earth‚Äôs axial tilt, are both responsible for what climate scientists today have dubbed as ‚Äúwarming‚Äù (or ‚Äúcooling,‚Äù depending on their agenda). In no way, shape, or form are humans warming or cooling the planet by driving SUVs or eating beef, in other words.


But NASA has thus far failed to set the record straight, and has instead chosen to sit silently back and watch as liberals freak out about the world supposedly ending in 12 years because of too much livestock, or too many plastic straws.


In the year 2000, NASA did publish information on its Earth Observatory website about the Milankovitch Climate Theory, revealing that the planet is, in fact, changing due to extraneous factors that have absolutely nothing to do with human activity. But, again, this information has yet to go mainstream, some 19 years later, which is why deranged, climate-obsessed leftists have now begun to claim that we really only have 18 months left before the planet dies from an excess of carbon dioxide (CO2).

text:
Exploring Human Impact On Climate Evolution

There is clear motivation to continue society's use of fossil fuels. They are the most readily commoditized of  all available fuel sources. The energy density packed into hydrocarbon molecules fueled the advance of industrial age, to which we are all indebted. The relatively few channels through which we can access these fuels has created tremendous ability to shape all aspects of any market, be it free or highly regulated OR DICTATED.
        What then, motivates the alleged scientific gathering of data to suggest that while the earth's climate is in regular flux, our use of natural resources has caused some kind of "unnatural" climate shift? We are nature, we are g-d. The earth is our gift to cherish or exploit as we see fit. And so, I personally conclude that most scientific explorations pertaining to the subject of climate chance are genuine efforts to help ensure a habitable earth for future generations.
       Everyone is wrong at some point and to some degree. The arguments against the potential for climate change seem to rely on meaningless, contrived comparisons and general dismissal. If scientists simply dismissed these rebuttals to their hypotheses we would not have any reason to take this matter seriously. The continuing and transparent work of science to strengthen its claims encourages the ongoing debate by adding new information to the pool of consideration. The FACTS are though, that whether or not fossil fuels exacerbate climate evolution, they take an enormous toll on the ecosystems that they come into contact with by changing the chemistry and topography of water and land more quickly than most life can adapt. Not to mention, the recovery of naturally sequestered hydrocarbons is the leading cause for land disputes among individuals, communities, and even governments.
       The extreme  defensive posture assumed by hydrocarbon fanatics eludes to the coordinated effort from the hydrocarbon industry to protect their market share. The campaign to discredit potential dangers of hydrocarbon exploitation dates back almost to the birth of the industry. Fossil fuel necessity is then, quite naturally reinforced by our current dependence on fossil fuels to maintain our modern lifestyle.  
          WE ARE MASTERS OF THIS EARTH. THERE IS NOTHING TO FEAR FROM OUR EXPLORING SOMETHING ''NEW''. No reasonable person expects hydrocarbons to immediately, or ever, become outlawed. There will likely always be sectors that rely on mined hydrocarbons for a variety of reasons. What is being suggested (by rational scientists) is that we as a species would very likely find it to be in our collective interest to diversify our energy portfolio to include systems that reduce the need for energy as they increase our ability to produce it anywhere, by individuals and municipalities alike. 
           I hope that really struck a nerve with everyone on both sides of this debate. It boils down to a dramatic shift in the balance of "power". Power to sustain, to produce, and to govern. That is why the hydrocarbon side of this debate is so acutely organized in their methods of planting doubt, by mis-aligning comparisons to reinforce any ideologies they deem beneficial to maintaining their market dominance. The balance of power is literally at stake. 
           Please remember, I think we are all as good as we can be, doing what we think will ensure a bright future. The only people who would demonize  each other for adhering to their respective beliefs cannot envision change and are looking to shore up the flimsy ground they themselves stand on. No one is bad for benefiting from/enjoying our current hydrocarbon exploitation, but to shirk responsibly for ensuring a productive earth for as long as possible is in my opinion inexcusable. Everyone is as much a part of the perceived problem as they are the perceived solution. Who wants tea?
             Best advice ever, because I like you, there is more to gain from an unbiased understanding of world history than a subjective interpretation of current events.

text:
CO2
is a greenhouse gas. That is it both absorbs and releases infrared
photons. Once released, there is one chance in 41,253 that infrared
photon will continue within one degree in the same direction. This
basically gives that photon a 50/50 chance of going either up or
down. Since the oceans cover about 71% of the Earth's surface, this
gives that photon about a 35% chance of hitting a body of water.
Infrared photons will not penetrate a body or water's surface, but
will instead excite an H2O molecule causing evaporation. H2O is the
primary greenhouse gas which prevents the Earth from having a climate
like our moon. Consequently the more CO2 we put into the atmosphere,
the more H2O gets into the atmosphere, the warmer the planet gets.
This is how a 40% increase in CO2 caused a 7% increase in absolute
humidity. The present increase in temperature due to this combination
of additional H2O and CO2 in the atmosphere is approximately .9C at
present. Because it takes a tremendous amount of time for the oceans
to heat, it will take centuries for the Earth to reach temperature
equilibrium. If we continue to inject CO2 into the atmosphere, that
heating process will continue to accelerate.

text:
Controversial climate tweet prompts concerns over deputy leader role

CONTROVERSIAL tweets about global warming from a Warwickshire council chief over have prompted a heated response.

Warwickshire County Council deputy leader Peter Butlin‚Äôs belief that climate change is not ‚Äòman made‚Äô has been questioned by the county‚Äôs green party leader Jonathan Chilvers who fears his view could have an impact on future decision making.

A tweet from a blogging climate change sceptic said older people were less likely to believe in the ‚Äòglobal warming scam‚Äô unlike the younger generation who were ‚Äòbrainwashed‚Äô in school, to which Coun Butlin replied older people who did believe in global warming did not have the excuse of being ‚Äòyoung and misguided‚Äô.

And in reply to criticism from Warwickshire residents Coun Butlin wrote: ‚ÄúI have yet to see real evidence that man‚Äôs CO2 emissions are a climate driver.

‚ÄúAs for does climate change exist? Of course it does, the climate has always changed. There is evidence going back thousands of years to support that.‚Äù

Coun Chilvers said his council colleague‚Äôs views were a concern since, as the county‚Äôs finance portfolio holder he ‚Äòheld the purse strings‚Äô, and the council had a policy to reduce CO2 emissions and responsibility for transport projects and flooding.

He added: ‚Äú‚ÄúCouncils need to play an increasingly important role if we are to adapt to climate change especially on issues like flooding. Yet Warwickshire council has a deputy leader who doesn‚Äôt think it exists and seems to think climate scientists are making it up to keep their jobs.

‚ÄúWe need our leaders to make good evidence based decisions for the future not spread half baked theories from a dark corner of the internet.‚Äù

Coun Butlin was reluctant to comment but was adamant his beliefs did not impact on council decisions.

He said: ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs my personal view and nothing to do with my role at the council.

‚ÄúIn my role as councillor I‚Äôve championed the use of electric cars, I‚Äôve championed recycling, and helped on a lot of environmental issues.‚Äù

Council leader Izzi Seccombe told the BBC while she did not agree with her deputy‚Äôs views, all councillors were entitled to their opinions and it was ‚Äòthe nature of politics‚Äô.

The beliefs echo those of President Donald Trump who declared global-warming as ‚Äòfake news‚Äô and last year pulled the US out the Paris agreement ‚Äì which aims to reduce greenhouse emission.

Around three per cent of scientists believe humans are not to blame for global warming, instead believing it is caused by natural forces.

text: Climate Change?  The climate is always changing.  Global Warming?  While going to the U of Arizona in the early 1970's the climate "genius'/scientists" were claiming we were entering another ice age.  They can not predict the weather from one day to the next, much years in the future.  Think about this:  The air we breath is about 77% Nitrogen, about 22% Oxygen, .93% Argon and only about .04 of 1% Carbon Dioxide and other trace gasses, dust, water, etc.  Do you really think that a fraction of 1 percent Carbon Dioxide can change our climate?  Let's get real and use a little common sense,

text: ¬†@Random The Wise¬† there is not just one natural cycle that occurs by clockwork, there are literally hundreds ranging across massive time spans. Decadel ocean oscillation, Milancovic cycles, pole shifts and incursions, grand solar maximums and minimums, el nino and el nina. Sometimes these overlap to either exaggerate or diminish the usual intensity of the cycle. Climate is just so hugely complicated, no one can predict it even 3 months from now but somehow Climate Models are believable for the next 100 years. You have to stop eating up the media hype and approach AGW with skepticism.

text:
I know I am quite late to this party, but does anyone have any opinions on why climate change is being denied. I try to hold an 'on the fence' opinion (or at least try to see both opinions) so I am wondering about the stances of both sides. From reading articles it seems there is little room to disagree about the effect we have on the environment. NASA released a graph showing the amount of carbon dioxide emission levels has never crossed a certain line of approximately 300, 000 parts per million. In recent years, we are at around 400, 000 parts per million. Does this seem big or small considering the advancement of technology over the years? "The planet's average surface temperature has risen about 2.0 degrees Fahrenheit (1.1 degrees Celsius) since the late 19th century, a change driven largely by increased carbon dioxide and other human-made emissions into the atmosphere.5 Most of the warming occurred in the past 35 years, with 16 of the 17 warmest years on record occurring since 2001. Not only was 2016 the warmest year on record, but eight of the 12 months that make up the year ‚Äî from January through September, with the exception of June ‚Äî were the warmest on record for those respective months" (NASA). If any would like to share their opinion I would be glad to read it. :)

Here is a link to the site if anyone is interested: https://climate.nasa.gov/evidence/

text:
Kevin - when I first heard about it 20 years ago I believed it. Now not so much.  I've learned a lot in that time, but most importantly to think for myself.  Climate change proponents tend to like to cite the record breaking temperatures as evidence, but if you look at the records the temperatures are breaking they were often set 50, 70, 100 years ago or more, which to me indicates that climate fluctuation is just a natural phenomena that occurs over time.  

How much light/heat energy the earth gets from the sun is the primary factor affecting earth's regional climates and that is in turn affected by three subsequent factors:

1. the earth's axial tilt which shifts over time from between 21¬∞ and 24¬∞ greatly affecting the amount of incident light energy that hits the north pole.  I would imagine the greater the tilt toward 24¬∞ (leaning more towards the sun) the less north pole ice we have.  As we tilt away the north pole ice will return and grow. 

2. the "wobble" of the earth as it spins through space.  The earth actually wobbles like a spinning top as it spins and sails through space.  This would also greatly affect the amount of incident light energy that reaches different regions of the earth.  And since the earth is relatively larger than a spinning top toy it wobbles much much more slowly quite possibly leading to brief periods (years) of anomalous weather that might be perceived by beings whose experiential time span is too short to be able to put it into proper perspective.

3. Earth's orbit around the sun.  The earth orbits the sun, not in a perfect circle, but rather in an ellipse, comparable to an oval.  And as earth orbits the sun and carves a path through space it almost certainly never follows the same exact path twice.  Some years we sail a little closer to the sun and some years we sail by a little further away.  By simply looking at the other planets in our solar system we can see how greatly weather and temperature are affected by how closely a planet orbits the sun.

author: Luis Sang

text:
Luis Sang - maybe hoax is too strong, but definitely a phenomena that is being misunderstood.  Earth's regional climates naturally fluctuate over time.  It's a result of the axial tilt of the earth, the earth's wobble, and the earth's orbital path as it sails through space and around the sun. All of those factors change over time and lead to changes in the amount of light energy that reaches different regions year to year, decade to decade and on and on to much larger time scales creating "ages", or eras. This creates weather patterns, which to beings with lives as short as ours, may seem seem anomalous but in the larger scheme of things is not extraordinary at all. 

If you wanted to look at the average climate for any region of the earth you'd have to look at more than just the last 2 or 300 years that we have been recording data which is just a firecracker in time.  The earth is approx. 4.5 billion years old. That's 4,500,000,000 and we've been recording data for only 200 or 300!  That's the equivalent of attempting to determine the average speed of a vehicle trip from Washington, D.C. to San Diego California by just looking at the cars average speed driving a few feet on Constitution Ave. in Washington D.C. 

So maybe hoax isn't right, but it's definitely poor science.

And it is absolutely the same in terms of objectivity to a research sponsored by say pharmaceutical or coal or energy industry. They a both biased. Everyone cites figures nobody has checked and is an instant expert on this topic. Which is of course laughable. Invariably an emotional element is added to leftists claims of people suffering and dying in floods, droughts, hurricanes, cold winters, hot summers etc. to compensate for the inconclusive data (if somebody bothers to check that date at all). text:
It wouldn't have anything to do when the fact that it would have cost the US billions of dollars and millions of jobs, would it?
Maybe its the fact that the Accord was a joke.
It didn't force Russia, China or India to actually reduce anything.
China and Russia would actually be allowed to increase their carbon emissions and we would have to pay India to reduce theirs.
It was a bad deal, all around.
It'll cost us jobs and revenue while the projected benefit would be .05 reduction in 20 years.

Secondly, I've noticed that people tend to think that conservatives hate nature or something (not necessarily this thread).
They fail to realize that we're the hunters, fishers, trappers, farmers ect.
We're very much in love with nature.
For a lot of us it's our bread and butter.
We just don't see why the US should sign a deal that will end up costing us even more money.

text:
Who expects to get free healthcare? Not me, but I expect that my tax covers healthcare like in civilized nations.

So you're happy to see your tax dollars cover tax cuts for the wealthy and military spending rather than meals on wheels and healthcare? And why do "muricans" think that it's a sign of entitlement that the government provides for health care? Do you really think it's a good system when you have to work 55 hrs/week, pay tax and STILL have to buy health insurance? And what if your condition isn't covered, or your insurance company claims it's preexisting condition, what then? Bank loan? And what happens if you find yourself unemployed and unable to keep your health insurance? 

And hospitals have to treat you in an emergency, if not they can turn you away if you can't pay. It's just stupid. So why do you pay tax? Why is it so wrong to have some of that back through healthcare?
